reviews.review_text: I'm a fan of both Thomas and Isaacson so I went into this wish really high expectations and this detailed book didn't disappoint. If you've read any of Evan Thomas' books such as "The Very Best Men: The Daring Early Years of the CIA" or "Sea of Thunder: Four Commanders and the Last Great Naval Campaign 1941-1945" then you will be familiar with his style of tracing the lives of several characters in one book. I have always enjoyed his style of biography that shifts from character to character in different chapters. Great read.

A wonderfully researched joint biography of six men whose intelligence, decency and outlook greatly influenced American foreign policy in the eventful period of the Second World War and early stages of the Cold War.  A joy to read - with insightful and often humorous anecdotes about their lives, a perfect blend of exposition about the decisions they faced and their personal lives.  The authors believe - with much basis - that the results of their decisions were on the whole, quite favorable to their country and the world.The choice of these six is a good one - the authors don't strain to create connections where they are slight - e.g., Kennan and McCloy don't seem to interact much - but it is true that the degree to which their backgrounds do intersect is remarkable.  A subplot is "American establishment" and the extent of its existence.  A shallow reader might conclude - partly because the connections are drawn so vividly - that this was a closed elite. But this was untrue. - and the authors do not try to paint it so.  McCloy's background was quite modest - Kennan was from Wisconsin, Acheson from a well-established but almost rural family in New Hampshire.  Although Acheson, Harriman, Lovett and Bohlen were finely educated at prep schools, it's also true that during the period of their youths, the two or three dozen most heralded prep schools graduated many many thousands of students - most of whom obviously did not become high officials in government.The authors rightly admire (with the exception of the internment of Japanese civilians) the policies of the United States government during the 1940s and early 1950s -- a period in which the Democratic Party dominated the federal government - despite the "Mr. Win the War" hat donned by FDR when war came - and his opening the top levels of government to more conservative Republican men.  The authors' admiration of their subjects does induce a certain share in their irritation at criticism - particularly from the right.It would be interesting to see another pair of authors create a similar book about those who took high places in the Eisenhower administration - some of whom - Forrestal, Dillon, the Dulles brothers and Nitze come to mind - had a similar background to these men.  I suspect if such a book shared the outlook of its subjects, and the time period of their period in power, the book might be darker - the U.S. rather powerless to prevent the deaths of approximately 30 million in the Great Leap Forward, the deep Soviet oppression over half of Europe, an escalating nuclear arms race.In a sense, this is the equally true dark side of what the world looked like AFTER the Wise men were in power - in 1939, there had been NO Communist China at all, the Soviet Union had NOT extended its grip over a hundred million Europeans. One should not overestimate what good these wise men were able to do.It's really a fine book - hugely informative, the writing a pleasure to read - you'll quite enjoy it.

As happens frequently in biographies, the authors fell in love with their subjects; praise for the 6 main members of the Cold War "Establishment" far outweighs criticism.  Averell Harriman and Dean Acheson get the most thorough attention among the 6 subjects, and rightfully so.I took away one star because the authors largely see the foreign policies of Republican presidents Ike, Nixon and Reagan through the eyes of the Wise Men, instead of objectively.  Only when Nixon "comes to his senses" and asks Acheson and Harriman for advice does he receive some praise.  Ike's foreign policy era is portrayed as one to be endured until the Wise Men are allowed back in the inner circle under JFK. Their total disdain for Reagan is clear; no mention of the reasons for end of the Cold War and Reagan's active part in it.However, the 5-star section of the book is clearly the LBJ-Vietnam era.  Wow, they really can't stand LBJ as a human being and politician, but his (and the Wise Men's) agony over the Vietnam war is written about almost lyrically.  The authors convey the complicated global factors of the war in an admirable, even-handed, almost sympathetic way.

A fascinating history of how six good friends changed the course of US history -- both in and out of the government.  The book actually showed how the "revolving door" actually was a benefit rather than a detriment to good governance.  Impressive men made impressive contributions to our country.

summary:
With a new introduction by the authors, this is the classic account of the American statesmen who rebuilt the world after the catastrophe of World War II.

A captivating blend of personal biography and public drama, The Wise Men introduces six close friends who shaped the role their country would play in the dangerous years following World War II. They were the original best and brightest, whose towering intellects, outsize personalities, and dramatic actions would bring order to the postwar chaos and leave a legacy that dominates American policy to this day: Averell Harriman, the freewheeling diplomat and Roosevelt’s special envoy to Churchill and Stalin; Dean Acheson, the secretary of state who was more responsible for the Truman Doctrine than Truman and for the Marshall Plan than General Marshall; George Kennan, self-cast outsider and intellectual darling of the Washington elite; Robert Lovett, assistant secretary of war, undersecretary of state, and secretary of defense throughout the formative years of the Cold War; John McCloy, one of the nation’s most influential private citizens; and Charles Bohlen, adroit diplomat and ambassador to the Soviet Union.
